title: How to Prepare for Your First Yoga Class at a Yoga Studio

steps.headline: Review information about the yoga class.
steps.description: Call the studio or check out its website for details about the class level and any prerequisites. EXPERT TIP																															Susana Jones, C-IAYT																Certified Yoga Therapist								Susana Jones is a Certified Yoga Therapist. Through her company, Urban Yogi LLC, she offers one-on-one Yoga as Therapy to reduce stress and pain associated with physical, mental, and emotional hardships. She carries credentials with the International Association of Yoga Therapists and Yoga Alliance and serves as a Mentor of Yoga Therapy for the internationally accredited Soul of Yoga. Online Yoga as Therapy sessions with Susana are available to people across the United States. She has a BA in International Spanish for Professions from the University of Colorado Boulder. Susana Jones, C-IAYT			Certified Yoga Therapist				What Our Expert Does: "I like to tell people coming to my yoga classes for the first time that they can't do anything wrong. It's important to come into class with an open mind and be willing to give it your best effort. You're not there to compete with anyone else, but to have a relaxing time and get into a peaceful, mindful headspace."

steps.headline: Inquire about the availability of a yoga mat.
steps.description: Some yoga studios provide yoga mats and others expect you to bring your own.

steps.headline: Avoid eating for several hours before class.
steps.description: Yoga instructors generally recommend that you do not eat right before class due to the extensive twisting and bending involved in yoga practice. However, this is entirely up to you and will be based on knowledge of your own body and whether you are affected by eating prior to physical activity.

steps.headline: Hydrate before a yoga class.
steps.description: This is especially important if you will be taking bikram yoga, which takes place in a heated room. In general, you'll want to avoid practicing yoga when dehydrated. Bring a water bottle and take sips from it during the class, if the instructor permits it.

steps.headline: Limit the use of scented lotions, perfumes and cologne.
steps.description: Yoga classes can cause you to sweat, which releases these scents into the air and can be problematic for other class participants who may be allergic to or distracted by these aromas.

steps.headline: Dress comfortably for yoga class.
steps.description: You might invest in yoga attire or simply wear comfortable athletic clothing. Avoid wearing overly baggy clothing, such as a t-shirt, because you might find yourself upside down with the t-shirt covering your face for extensive periods of time. Wear layers in cold weather. To keep your muscles warm, you might start the yoga class wearing several layers and can remove them during class once your muscles are warm.

steps.headline: Bring a towel.
steps.description: Depending on the demands of the yoga class and how much you exert yourself, you may sweat a lot.

steps.headline: Arrive early to claim floor space.
steps.description: Particularly in crowded yoga studios, arriving early is a good idea so that you can find an ideal spot in the room.

steps.headline: Avoid disrupting the class.
steps.description: If you do arrive late, enter quietly. Some yoga classes begin with chants or other meditative practices. Turn off your cell phone. For many styles of yoga, instructors create a serene ambiance that requires a meditative silence throughout the entire class. Turn off your cell phone before entering the studio to preserve the serene environment.

steps.headline: Inform the yoga instructor of injuries or physical limitations.
steps.description: This is useful information for the instructor who may then suggest modifications for particular yoga poses and positions. It is also a courteous gesture so that a yoga instructor understands why you are not participating in some of the yoga poses.
